Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Theorem, Algorithm, and Applications of Computational Quasiconformal Geometry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Quasiconformal geometry has showed its power and flexibility in complex analysis, differential equations, function theory, and topology. Computational quasiconformal geometry focuses on algorithmic study of quasiconformal geometry theory, which links very pure areas of abstract mathematics to concrete engineering applications. This project addresses a number of fundamental engineering problems where quasiconformal geometry can provide a key insight, including building a variational framework of computing the optimal diffeomorphism between surfaces with general topologies, building a theoretically well sound framework to model shape space of surfaces, and building anisotropic models which are widely observed in various areas including wireless sensor networks, computer graphics, and solid mechanics. Expected results include the exploration of computational theorems, new models, and novel geometric algorithms with provable performance guarantee.

This interdisciplinary project provides the bridge between quasiconformal geometry and applications in broad engineering fields by identifying important geometric problems in computer graphics, computer vision, geometric modeling, and wireless sensor networks as well as supplying computational theorems and efficient algorithmic solutions based on quasiconformal geometry theory. It is expected that the exploration will reveal key insights of fundamental problems in those fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational conformal and quasiconformal geometry focuses on algorithmic study of conformal and quasiconformal geometry theory and links very pure areas of abstract mathematics to many engineering applications. The project aims to discover, investigate, and explore theorems and computational algorithms on conformal and quasiconformal geometry and produce theoretically sound and efficient solutions for emerging applications in computer graphics, computer vision, modeling, and wireless sensor networks. The project has developed computational algorithms for Teichmuller shape space with results applied for surface indexing, clustering, and morphing. The project has also developed theorems and algorithms to compute seamless isotropic and anisotropic mesh models. Many key problems in wireless sensor networks can be modeled geometrically. The project has applied conformal and quasiconformal geometry to design a series of algorithms for wireless sensor network operation.

The findings in the project have been presented in high-profile conferences and journals, including ACM MobiHoc, IEEE INFOCOM, IEEE ICDCS, CAD, CAGD, and IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking.  Results of the project have been summarized in springer book “Conformal Geometry - Computational Algorithms and Engineering Applications”. The book has presented a series of computational algorithms of conformal and quasiconformal geometry and discussed their implementation issues from the engineering point of view. The book spends each chapter on a specific application field including computer graphics, computer vision, geometric modeling, medical imaging, and wireless sensor networks, discussing the fundamental problems of a field and how conformal and quasiconformal geometry tackles them in a theoretically elegant and computationally efficient way. 

This project has a broad impact on multi-disciplinary research and education. The algorithms developed in the project benefit several fields ranging from computer graphics and computer vision research to wireless sensor networks design. In the long term, it will foster multi-disciplinary research opportunities, effectively strengthening the research competitive edge of University of Louisiana at Lafayette. The PI has lectured frequently at graduate level seminars and institutions to share research results with a broad audience from different fields. The PI has also actively incorporated geometric algorithms and particular research findings from the project into related courses by the PI, in order to popularize these new computational geometry algorithms and attract more students into this emerging area. Five graduate students at the Ph.D. level are recruited and involved in the proposed research project. With the success of the project, we expect that the graduate students are trained and become the next generation of elite scientists and engineers. Moreover, the PI has been committed to the mission of developing and improving the participation of underrepresented groups. Three students with one PhD candidate, one at the master level, and one freshman from minority groups have been worked with the PI on the research projects. The PI further partners with existing university recruitment mechanisms including the McNair Scholars and LS-LAMP programs to substantially increase the number of underrepresented students completing degrees in computer science area.
